Leveraging 60 years of space-based Earth observation, the EIC will use life-saving data to tackle the climate crisis at home.

Enceladus, Saturn's icy moon, is known for its geysers that erupt with water from a subsurface ocean. 

Scientists have just detected phosphorus—an uncommon element that's a key building block for life—in the plumes that these geysers spray: https://go.nasa.gov/43FVtY1

Another spacewalk in the books! 

Today’s spacewalk concluded at 2:17pm ET (1817 UTC) and lasted 5 hours and 35 minutes. Steve Bowen and @Astro_Woody installed a new roll-out solar array and completed numerous additional tasks outside the @Space_Station.
Watch the @Space_Station's new roll-out solar array begin to unfurl in a process that takes about 12 minutes to complete. This is the helmet camera view from astronaut Steve Bowen:

Spacewalkers Steve Bowen and @Astro_Woody have successfully installed the roll-out solar array and released hinge bolts. The duo will move on to work-ahead tasks as they wait for the next eclipse to unfold the solar array. Watch live... http://nasa.gov/live

Astronauts-eye view 

Take a look through the helmet cams of @Astro_Woody and Steve Bowen as they prepare to install a roll-out solar array during today's spacewalk.

Suits are set to battery power and today's spacewalk is underway!

This is Hoburg's second spacewalk and Bowen's 10th—tying a record for most spacewalks made by a U.S. astronaut.

How do we know what Earth's climate was like long ago? If you look closely, there are clues just about everywhere across our globe. Some are easy to see and others are more subtle. 
@NASAClimate
 scientist Dr. Gavin Schmidt explains.
